topic.name: World Religions & Modern Secular Worldviews
topic.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for World Religions & Modern Secular Worldviews in History & Social Studies

objectives.objective_text: Identify that some people don't believe in God.
Name 'Nature' as all there is for them.
Identify famous atheists.
Identify Hinduism and Buddhism.
Name India as where they started.
Identify Yoga as a Hindu practice.
Identify sharing that is forced.
Name the government as the boss of everything.
Identify the hammer and sickle symbol.
Identify 'My truth' vs. 'The Truth'.
Name the idea that there are no rules.
Identify the phrase 'Who are you to judge?'
Identify Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.
Name Abraham as the father of them all.
Identify Jerusalem as a holy city for all three.
Identify what makes a person a person.
Name God as the one who gives us value.
Identify human rights coming from God.
Recall that they think the world happened by accident.
Observe that they trust science instead of the Bible.
Recall that they believe you are born again and again.
Observe statues of Buddha.
Recall that they don't want people to go to church.
Observe that people are not free.
Recall that the Bible says some things are always true.
Observe people disagreeing about what is right.
Recall that they all believe in One God.
Observe a Synagogue, Church, and Mosque.
Recall that other ideas say we are just animals or accidents.
Observe that every person is special.
Summarize the belief that there is no God.
Explain 'Naturalism' (only what we see is real).
Explain Secular Humanism.
Defend the existence of the soul and mind against materialism.
Summarize the idea of Karma (what goes around comes around).
Explain Reincarnation.
Explain the difference between Pantheism (all is god) and Theism.
Defend the Christian view of the person vs. the absorption of the self.
Summarize the idea that everyone should be equal (same money).
Explain who Karl Marx was.
Explain the failure of command economies.
Defend the biblical right to private property.
Summarize the idea that 'what is true for you might not be true for me'.
Explain why Relativism makes it hard to say 'Stop' to bad things.
Explain why 'tolerance' has changed meaning.
Defend the exclusivity of Christ in a pluralistic society.
Summarize the key book for each (Torah, Bible, Quran).
Explain that Christians believe Jesus is the Son of God.
Explain the Trinity (Christianity) vs. Unitarian Monotheism (Judaism/Islam).
Defend the uniqueness of the Christian Gospel.
Summarize the Christian view: Made in God's Image, Fallen in Sin.
Explain the Secular view: Advanced animal.
Explain why only Christianity offers true dignity.
Defend the sanctity of life from conception to natural death.
Compare Creation with Evolution.
Analyze the logical consequences of Atheism (no ultimate purpose).
Interpret the 'God of the Gaps' argument.
Connect Naturalism to Materialism.
Compare the many gods of Hinduism with the no-god of Buddhism.
Analyze the Four Noble Truths of Buddhism.
Interpret the goal of Nirvana/Moksha (escaping the cycle).
Connect the Caste System to Hindu beliefs.
Compare owning your own house with the government owning it.
Analyze the view that history is a class struggle (Rich vs. Poor).
Interpret the phrase 'Religion is the opium of the people'.
Connect Communism to the persecution of Christians.
Compare absolute truth with feelings.
Analyze the rejection of 'Metanarratives' (Big Stories).
Interpret the deconstruction of language.
Connect Relativism to the breakdown of morality.
Compare the Jewish Saturday Sabbath with Christian Sunday.
Analyze the differing views of Jesus in the three faiths.
Interpret the concept of 'Covenant' in Judaism vs. Islam.
Connect the split between Ishmael and Isaac to modern conflict.
Compare being made by God with being an accident.
Analyze how worldview affects how we treat the weak.
Interpret the Eastern view of the self (illusion) vs. Christian (real).
Connect the doctrine of the Fall to the reality of evil.
Evaluate the problem of objective morality without God.
Evaluate the ethical implications of Karma (blaming the victim).
Evaluate the death toll of Communist regimes in the 20th century.
Evaluate the self-defeating nature of Relativism ('It is absolutely true that there are no absolute truths').
Evaluate the historical interaction of the three faiths.
Evaluate the implications of Transhumanism.
Construct an internal critique of the Atheist worldview.
Synthesize the rise of the 'New Atheism'.
Construct a critique of the cyclic view of history.
Synthesize the spread of Buddhism across Asia.
Construct a critique of Dialectical Materialism.
Synthesize the appeal of Marxism as a Christian heresy (salvation without God).
Construct a defense of the Correspondence Theory of Truth.
Synthesize the impact of Postmodernism on art and culture.
Construct a comparative theology of Salvation (Law vs. Grace vs. Submission).
Synthesize the geopolitical impact of the Abrahamic faiths.
Construct a comparison of the 'Self' in Modernity vs. Christianity.
Synthesize the redemption of the body in the Resurrection.
